items.title: Non-Breaking Hyphen Entity Being Replaced with Lowline Entity in Android Email Clients
items.body:
Android email clients are replacing all ‑ non-breaking hyphen entities with lowline entity in Android email clients.

This is only happening on serif fonts and works fine when switch just the font to a sans-serif. Researching shows that Android does this with characters that fonts do not have but this is a standard email default font Georgia.

Example of HTML below:

<table width="100%" border="0" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="max-width: 640px;">
  <tr>
      <td width="100%">
          <table width="100%" border="0" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="max-width: 640px;">
              <tr>
                  <td width="25" style="font-size:1px; line-height:1px;"  class="mobile_width_spacer_single">
                      <img width="25" border="0" src="images/spacer50.gif" style="display:block; padding:0; margin:0; border:none;" class="mobile_width_spacer_single" />
                  </td>
                  <td style="font-family: Georgia, serif; font-size: 75px; line-height:80px; color: #000000 !important; color: #000000; text-align: center; letter-spacing: 0px;" class="oneline_a1">
                      <a href="${clickthrough('')}" target="_blank" width="100%" height="100%" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration: none;">
                          <span style="color:#000000!important;font-size:75px;line-height:80px;text-decoration: none;" class="oneline_a1"><font color="000000">
                             New Straight‑Fit Jeans
                          </font></span>
                      </a>
                  </td>
                  <td width="25" style="font-size:1px; line-height:1px;"  class="mobile_width_spacer_single">
                      <img width="25" border="0" src="images/spacer50.gif" style="display:block; padding:0; margin:0; border:none;" class="mobile_width_spacer_single" />
                  </td>
              </tr>
          </table>
      </td>
  </tr>
</table>

Any assistance/feedback into this would be greatly appreciated.

I know there are many threads about this error, but I can't see where I've gone wrong in my code.

Being new to shiny, I'm having a hard time debugging this error. 
When trying to plot the progress of my algorithm, using `plotly`, I'm getting the error `$ is invalid for atomic vectors`.

I am currently generating in trimodal gaussian mixture in IR3  and I am trying to use the K means algorithm I made myself to sort the data that has been generated.

My R script is fine and works.
melange_mix take two parameters: 

    theta ( pi = vector of proportions ( for instance (1/2,1/4,1/4)  ) , 
            mu = data.frame of the means of each gaussian law ( X Y Z columns ) 

meaning each j row is the mu_j mean vector of the number j gaussian law
and sig is a list of every covariance/variance matrix 

state_ini takes two parameters the data generated from the previous function and the number of desired clusters you want to generate and returns 

state which is a list of ( nb_iter = number of iterations of the algorithm , barycentres = dataframe of 3 column X Y z containing the mean of each cluster and donnees= dataframe of the data X Y Z and classes column containing the clusters )

kmeans_update give the +1 iteration of the algorithm given a state list.
and generates a plot.

kmeans goes until convergence of the kmeans algorithm.

The R script is fully functioning but when trying to generate data in my shiny ( using the generate button ) so I can use state_ini to plot it the first iteration on my first plotoutput I get this error.

Here is the ui shinyApp:

                     selected = "sig_ind")),

***server.r***

                choices = list("Bimodal" = "pi_bimodal",
                "Trimodal" = "pi_trimodal"),
                selected = "pi_bimodal"
            ),
            checkboxGroupInput(
                "Moyennes",
                h3("Choix de moyennes"),
                choices = list(
                    "Proches" = "mu_p",
                    "Eloignées" = "mu_e",
                    "Croisées" = "mu_c"
                ),
                selected = "mu_p"
            ),
            checkboxGroupInput(
                "Variances",
                h3("Choix des matrices de Covariance"),
                choices = list("Corrélées" = "sig_ind",
                "Indépendantes" = "sig_corr"),
                 selected = "sig_ind")),
        sliderInput(
            "n",
            "Nombre d'observations:",
            value = 500,
            min = 1,
            max = 1000
        ),
        h2("Algorithme des K-means"),
        splitLayout(
            h3("Choix du nombre de classes"),
            sliderInput("K", "Nombre de classes", 1, 10, 2, 1)
        ),
        checkboxGroupInput(
            "dist",
            h3("Choix de la distance"),
            choices = list("Distance euclidienne", "Distance absolue"),
            selected = "dist_euclide"
        ),
  splitLayout(plotOutput("plot"),                                        
  plotOutput("plot2"))
        ))

server.r

server <- function(input, output) {
        dataInput <- eventReactive(input$generer, {
            theta <- list(pi = pi_trimodal, mu = input$Moyennes,
                          sig = input$Variances)
            realisation <- melange_mix(input$n, theta)
            state_ini(realisation)
        })

        output$plot <- renderPlotly({
            kmeans_update(dataInput())
        })

        output$plot2 <- renderPlotly({
            K <- input$K
            n <- input$n
            distance <- input$dist
            moyennes <- input$Moyennes
            variances <- input$Variances
            theta <-
                list(pi = pi_trimodal,mu = input$Moyennes, 
                     sig = input$Variances)

            realisation <- melange_mix(n, theta)                
            test <- state_ini(realisation, K)
            kmeans(test, dist_euclide)
        })
    }

run

shinyApp(ui, server)

Thank you

public Page1()

        powerPointBrowser1.Navigate(strFileName);
        powerPointBrowser1.LoadCompleted += powerPointBrowser1_LoadCompleted;
    }

This is my powerPoint1Browser_LoadCompleted method:

private void powerPointBrowser1_LoadCompleted(object sender, NavigationEventArgs e)
    {
        oDocument = powerPointBrowser1.Document;

        oPPApplication = oPPPresentation.Application;

items.title: Node.JS router get returning ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE page error
items.body:
I'm building a node.JS app with express.js, which is basically is a bridge to processes in SQL Server.

So I have this router:

router.get('/runpr/:ref', function(req, res, next) {

var p1 = req.params.ref;
execSQLQuery("EXEC SP_PROCESSA_PREMIO "+p1, function(result, err) {
    var response = '';
    if ( err != null ) { 
        // change error to node errors
        response = [{
            A_STATUS: 0,
            MSG: err.originalError.info.message,
            FINISHED: new Date(Date.now())
        }];  
    } else {
        response = result.recordset;
    }

    res.json( response );
});

})

The called function execSQLQuery:

function execSQLQuery(sqlQry, callback) {
var request = new sql.Request();
request.query(sqlQry, function(err, recordset) {
    callback(recordset, err);
});

}

The SQL connection is working fine for other queries, but this particular PROCEDURE is called from node and it takes 3 minutes, more or less. The procedure always returns me a dataset with the SQL error or a successful outcome. But in this case, when I browse to the router, it takes some time then to return me the error ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE.

When I check SQL Server, the procedure is still running, I was assuming there's a mssql-node timeout, so I set up:>

var config = {
    user: 'xxxx',
    password: 'xxx',
    server: 'xxxx',
    database: 'xxxx',
    connectionTimeout: 500000,
    requestTimeout: 500000
}

And also this, for node itself:

// listen and timeout
var server = app.listen(app.get('port'))
server.timeout = 500000;

None of them solved the problem...

2) Once the user ID is passed into sitecore, I need sitecore to display a unique page depending on the users choice of widgets that they create. Also, is it possible to create an experience editor experience for the end users to use? Those are my two big questions.

items.body_markdown:
I read that in order to compute the convolution of two signals x,y (1D for example), the naïve method takes `O(NM)`.

However FFT is used to compute `FFT^-1(FFT(x)FFT(y))`, which takes `O(N log(N))`, in the case where N>M.

I wonder why is this complexity considered better than the former one, as M isn't necessarily bigger than log(N). Moreover, M is very often the length of a filter, which doesn't scale with the signal to be filtered, and will actually provide us with a complexity more similar to `O(N)` than to `O(N^2)`.
items.title: How Fast is Convolution Using FFT
items.body:
I read that in order to compute the convolution of two signals x,y (1D for example), the naïve method takes O(NM).

However FFT is used to compute FFT^-1(FFT(x)FFT(y)), which takes O(N log(N)), in the case where N>M.

I wonder why is this complexity considered better than the former one, as M isn't necessarily bigger than log(N). Moreover, M is very often the length of a filter, which doesn't scale with the signal to be filtered, and will actually provide us with a complexity more similar to O(N) than to O(N^2).

items.body_markdown:
I'm implementing Prequential Evaluation in R using `RMOA`. 

This isn't too important for the question, but to basically this evaluates  performance of a stream mining classifier by *first testing*  and *then training* the model for every observation in a stream.

I have it largely completed, except I'm encountering this error message when making predictions:

>number of items to replace is not a multiple of replacement length

I'm using the Iris dataset, and strangely it predicts class labels and trains for the first 50 observations as I would expect. For the remaining 100, however, it produces the above error. The dataset is in its default order :

    Label        Number

    Setosa       50
    Versicolor   50
    Virginica    50

This means that for whatever reason, the model is making predictions on all of the Setosa observations, and then produces this error for the other two class labels. If I randomise the rows I encounter the same problem; as soon a second class label is encountered the error is produced.

I've read similar questions surrounding this error, such as [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22099461/r-number-of-items-to-replace-is-not-a-multiple-of-replacement-length-results-h). None of the existing question seem to address the problem in the context of classification.

Relevant R code:

    require(RMOA)
    require(stream)
    
    #data<-iris[sample(nrow(iris)),] #use this for randomising the iris dataset
    df = datastream_dataframe(as.data.frame(iris))
    
    opts<-MOAoptions(model="HoeffdingTree")
    tree<-HoeffdingTree(control = opts)
    mymodel <- NULL
    
    i<- 1
    #Iterate over the stream until the stream is empty
    repeat
    {
        element <- df$get_points(1)
      
        #Check to see if stream is empty - not elegant but it works just now
        if(is.null(element$Species)){
            break
        }
        
        #Prequential evaluation
        tryCatch(
        {
            #First test
            pred <- RMOA:::predict.MOA_trainedmodel(mymodel, element, type="response")
            cat("Tested element ", i, "Pred: ",pred, ". Label: ", element$Species,"\n")
          
            #Then train
            #If first element in stream, the model is initially trained in the error block below
            if(!i==1){
                mymodel <<- trainMOA(model = mymodel$model, 
                    formula = Species ~ Sepal.Length + Sepal.Width + Petal.Length + Petal.Width, 
                    data = datastream_dataframe(element))
                cat("Trained model using element ", i,"\n")
            }
        },
        
        error = function(err){
            cat("Error processing element ", i,"\n")
            if(i==1){
                cat("The model was initially untrained.\n")
                mymodel <<- trainMOA(model = tree, Species ~ Sepal.Length + Sepal.Width + Petal.Length + Petal.Width, data = datastream_dataframe(element))
            }
            else{
                message(err)
            }
        })#end try-catch block
      
        i<<- i+ 1
    }#end while


Note that initially the model is set to `null`. For the first observation, the attempted prediction will produce an error since the model is untrained. This is handled within the `try-catch`. All subsequent observations should be tested before training.

What is wrong with my model that it produces this error?

In Firefox, there are two ways to launch an extension.

The first is the normal way:

[![Extension_Launched_Normal_Way][1]][1]

The second way is if the extension is launched from the toolbar overflow. This mode occurs if A) The browser window has a small width or B) the user puts the extension in the toolbar overflow. 

[![Extension_Launched_From_Overflow][2]][2]

I need to detect if the extension has been launched from the toolbar overflow, or through the normal method. How can I do this? 

I need to do this because if the extension is launched the normal way, the width of the extension can be set to any value. However, if the extension is launched from the toolbar overflow, the width cannot be set to a custom value that exceeds the width of the toolbar overflow, otherwise this will occur:

[![Extension_Launched_From_Toolbar_Overflow_Broken][3]][3]

As such, I need to know when the extension is being launched from the toolbar overflow in order to avoid setting a custom width for the extension.


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/r4M4G.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/oqklX.jpg
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/MRL38.png

But as triggers have a cost, I must be careful how I use these functions.

I checked the pricing plans to see if I can understand how functions are charged. I found 4 parameters that charge a single function:



**Invocation**: I understood this to be the number of time a message is sent.

**GB-second**: No idea.

**CPU-second**: No idea.

**Networking**: I understood this is only charged if my function affects anything beyond firebase products like (cloud-storage, real time database).

Questions:
---------

1. Is it normal to invoke a function like I am doing (is it a good practice, considering large amount of users)?

2. What is the real meaning of the above 4 parameters (because I dont seem to understand all of them especially the GB and CPU stuff)?

3. For a Flame plan how many (possible) users are okay to invoke functions on each sent message?

4. Should I worry about functions too much in terms of cost, because firebase seems to charge on every bit of a function (this is my opinion)?

Thanks all.

Is it true that statements like `something <- stuff` are always evaluated in Haskell, even when `something` is not called in the rest of the code ? (is `something <- stuff` called an "action" ? - I don't know the technical wording).

If this is true, I have another question.

I have some code starting like this:

    computeContour3d voxel voxmax level = do
        voxelmax <- somefunction voxel
        let max' = fromMaybe voxelmax voxmax

That is, if the argument `voxmax` is not `Nothing`, then `voxelmax` is not necessary, since `max' = fromJust voxmax` in this case. Therefore, if the answer to my first question is "Yes", how could I avoid the evaluation of `voxelmax` when it is not necessary ?
items.title: Evaluation of "something <- stuff" statements
items.body:
Is it true that statements like something <- stuff are always evaluated in Haskell, even when something is not called in the rest of the code ? (is something <- stuff called an "action" ? - I don't know the technical wording).

If this is true, I have another question.

I have some code starting like this:

computeContour3d voxel voxmax level = do
    voxelmax <- somefunction voxel
    let max' = fromMaybe voxelmax voxmax

That is, if the argument voxmax is not Nothing, then voxelmax is not necessary, since max' = fromJust voxmax in this case. Therefore, if the answer to my first question is "Yes", how could I avoid the evaluation of voxelmax when it is not necessary ?

I am writing SQL grammar using Antlr 3.5 (which I cannot share due to company policy).<br>
I am providing only for the statements which I need to parse but the grammar is huge and complex.<br>
I ran into "code too large" issue where the generated java file was exceeding 65535 bytes- sometimes in static initializer, other times in some method.

As suggested at various places, I split the grammar into multiple grammars and used them via import keyword.

This approach is working fine for now but I have to keep adding to this grammar 
and I believe at some point it will again run into this code too large problem.<br>
Also, I do not know exactly how much gain I have by splitting the grammar.

My questions are-

 1. How do we know we are nearing code too large problem again?
 2. Is there a way by which we can measure exactly how much improvement/gain
    we are getting by splitting the grammars.
 3. The generated files are still huge - SqlParserParser.java is 1.77MB and 
SqlParser_SqlSubParser.java is 1.36MB. <br>
Is the file size an indication of this problem?
 4. Is there anything else that can also be done besides grammar splitting.

Few points-

 1. I cannot switch to Antlr4 as of now.
 2. Please try not to down vote my question for the lack of example as I cannot post the real grammar and a small example would not recreate my problem.

Thanks.
items.title: ANTLR: How to anticipate and avoid "code to large"?
items.body:
I am writing SQL grammar using Antlr 3.5 (which I cannot share due to company policy).
I am providing only for the statements which I need to parse but the grammar is huge and complex.
I ran into "code too large" issue where the generated java file was exceeding 65535 bytes- sometimes in static initializer, other times in some method.

As suggested at various places, I split the grammar into multiple grammars and used them via import keyword.

This approach is working fine for now but I have to keep adding to this grammar and I believe at some point it will again run into this code too large problem.
Also, I do not know exactly how much gain I have by splitting the grammar.

My questions are-

  1. How do we know we are nearing code too large problem again?
  2. Is there a way by which we can measure exactly how much improvement/gain we are getting by splitting the grammars.
  3. The generated files are still huge - SqlParserParser.java is 1.77MB and SqlParser_SqlSubParser.java is 1.36MB.
    Is the file size an indication of this problem?
  4. Is there anything else that can also be done besides grammar splitting.

Few points-

  1. I cannot switch to Antlr4 as of now.
  2. Please try not to down vote my question for the lack of example as I cannot post the real grammar and a small example would not recreate my problem.

Thanks.
